text: Douglas Jamieson (14 April 1880 – 31 May 1952) was a Scottish Unionist politician and judge. == Biography == Jamieson was born on 14 April 1880 to Violet and William Jamieson, a merchant. Educated at Cargilfield School, Fettes College, the University of Glasgow and the University of Edinburgh, He was admitted as an advocate in 1911 and became a King's Counsel in 1926. Jamieson was an unsuccessful candidate for Stirling and Falkirk in 1929 and was elected for Glasgow Maryhill in October 1931, holding the seat until his retirement in 1935. He was Solicitor General for Scotland from October 1933 until March 1935, and Lord Advocate from March to October 1935. He was appointed a Privy Counsellor in May 1935. On his resignation, he was appointed in November 1935 to the bench of the Court of Session, with the judicial title Lord Jamieson, replacing Lord Blackburn. He held this post until his death in 1952 aged 72. == References == Category:1880 births Category:1952 deaths Category:Members of the Parliament of the United Kingdom for Scottish constituencies Category:Unionist Party (Scotland) MPs Category:UK MPs 1931–1935 Category:Lord Advocates Category:People educated at Cargilfield School Category:People educated at Fettes College Category:Alumni of the University of Edinburgh Category:Solicitors General for Scotland Jamieson Category:Members of the Privy Council of the United Kingdom Category:Members of the Faculty of Advocates Category:Scottish Queen's Counsel Category:Queen's Counsel 1901–2000 Category:Maryhill
title: Douglas Jamieson, Lord Jamieson
